turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: You'll get awful mad, John. I done a Sin!

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: John, don't be mad! Don't be mad! I was just playing with it! I didn't tell no one!

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: I want to go upstairs. It's cold and spidery down here. I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Now listen to me, Pearl. You and me is runnin' off tonight.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: If we stay here somethin' awful will happen to us.

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: Won't Daddy Powell take care of us?

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Please be quiet -- Oh please, Pearl!

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Get in the skiff, Pearl, goodness, goodness, hurry!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: Hurt her nothin'! Wash her's more like it!  Ruby!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: I'm butcherin' my hog myself, smokin' the hams, and cannin' the sausage.  You-all have your work cut out!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: I didn't figger ye rowed that skiff from Parkersburg!

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: About them Kings. That the Queen found down on the sandbar in the skiff that time.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: Kings! Why, honey, there was only one.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: I mind you said there was two.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: John, when your Dad says 'come', you should mind him.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: This watch is the nicest watch I ever had.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: A feller can't just go around with run-down, busted watches.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Why, he told me what fine little lambs you and your sister both was.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Did you hear what I said, son?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Married! We have decided to go to Sistersville tomorrow, and when we come back --

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: You ain't my Dad! You won't never be my Dad!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: -- and when we come back, we'll all be friends -- and share our fortunes together, John!

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: You think you can make me tell! But I won't! I won't! I won't!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Are we keeping secrets from each other, little lad?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: What's taking you so long about it?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: What's that you're playing with, boy?

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Pearl's junk. Mom gets mad when she plays out here and don't clean up afterward.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Your mother says you tattled on me, boy. She says you told her that I asked you where that money was hid.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: That wasn't very nice of you, John. Have a heart, boy.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: She thinks that money's in the river, but you and me, we know better, don't we, boy?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: The summer is young yet, little lad.  Pearl?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: I thought I told you to keep your mouth shut --

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: NO, -- it ain't fair to make Pearl tell when she swore she wouldn't. I'll tell.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: All right boy: where's the money?

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: In the cellar. Buried under a stone in the floor.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Go ahead of me -- the both of you.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You don't reckon I'd leave you.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Now where, boy? Mind; no tricks. I can't abide liars.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Under the stone in the floor.

turns.speaker: JOHN HARPER
turns.text: Pearl, shut up! Pearl, you swore!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You could save him, little bird.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: John's a feller who likes to keep secrets.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: I knowed your Daddy.  And do you know what your Daddy said to me? He said, "Tell my little girl Pearl there's to be no secrets between her and you."

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: You're just foolin'! My name's Pearl.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Tst-tst! Then I reckon I'll have to try again! Where's the money hid?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You see? We can't have anything to do with John.  You and me will go down to the parlor.

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: Tell me another secret about my Dad.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Where's the money hid? Tell me, you little wretch, or I'll tear your arm off!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Why, sure. And there's fried chicken and candied sweets and cornsticks and apple cobbler!

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: Can I have my supper please?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Yes. But first of all we'll have a little talk.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Just tell me now; where's the money hid?

turns.speaker: PEARL HARPER
turns.text: But I swore. I promised John I wouldn't tell.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: JOHN -- DOESN'T -- MATTER! Can't I get that through your head, you poor, silly, disgusting little wretch!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You're Ruby, ain't you, my child?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Surely. I'd like to talk to you, my dear.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Will you buy me a choclit sody?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Why, you're the purtiest girl I've seen in all my wandering. Didn't nobody never tell you that, Ruby?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: There's two new ones over at your place, ain't there Ruby?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Ahhh.  And is there -- a doll?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Only she won't never let me play with it.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: A strange woman is a narrow pit!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: It is my shame -- my crown of thorns. And I must wear it bravely.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: She turned me out of the bed.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: What do you figure to do?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Do? Why stay and take care of them little kids. Maybe it was never meant for a woman like Willa to taint their young lives.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: That's mighty brave of you, Reverend.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: I reckon it's been ordained this way, Brother Spoon.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Didn't -- didn't she leave no word?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: A scrawl. On a piece of notepaper on the bureau.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: She'll come draggin' her tail back home.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: She'll not be back. I reckon I'd be safe in promisin' you that.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Maybe she's just run off on a spree.

turns.speaker: WILLA HARPER
turns.text: John: take that look offen your face and act nice.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: He don't mean no impudence; do you, boy?  Do you, boy? Ah, many's the time poor Brother Ben told me about these youngins.

turns.speaker: WILLA HARPER
turns.text: John, Mr. Powell has got something to tell you.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Well, John, the night before your father died, he told me what he did with that money.

turns.speaker: WILLA HARPER
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Harry! I didn't know! I thought maybe --

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You thought, Willa, that the moment you walked in that door I'd start in to pawing you in the abominable way men are supposed to do on their wedding night. Ain't that right, now?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: I think it's time we got one thing perfectly clear, Willa. Marriage to me represents a blending of two spirits in the sight of Heaven.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Do you want more children, Willa?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: It's the business of our marriage to mind those two you have now -- not to beget more.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You were listening outside the parlor window.

turns.speaker: WILLA HARPER
turns.text: It's not in the river, is it Harry?

turns.speaker: WILLA HARPER
turns.text: Ben never told you he throwed it in the river? Did he?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: You're Miz Cooper, I take it.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: It's about that John and that Pearl?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Shall I tell ye the little story of Right-Hand-Left-Hand -- the tale of Good and Evil?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: It was with this left hand that old brother Cain struck the blow that laid his brother low --

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: She run off with a drummer one night. Durin' prayer-meetin'.

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Somewheres down river! Parkersburg, mebbe! -- Cincinnati! -- One of them Sodoms on the Ohio River.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: She took them kids with her?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Heaven only knows what unholy sights and sounds those innocent little babes has heard in the dens of perdition where she dragged them!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: Right funny, hain't it, how they rowed all the way up river in a ten- foot john-boat!

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: Gracious, gracious! You are a good woman, Miz Cooper!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: How you figgerin' to raise them two without a woman?

turns.speaker: PREACHER
turns.text: The Lord is merciful! What a day is this! -- And there's little John!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: What are you after them for?

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: I'm givin' you to the count of three to get out that screen door; then I'm a-comin' across this kitchen shootin'!

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: Not this time! It was just one youngin -- a little boy babe. And do you know who he was, children?

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: Ruby, you didn't have no money to buy this.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This man down at the Drugstore...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Miz Cooper. I never went to sewin' lessons all them times.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This gentleman warn't like them! He just give me a sody and the book.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: He never asked me for nothin'.

turns.speaker: RACHEL COOPER
turns.text: He must have wanted somethin', Ruby. A man don't waste time on a girl unless he gets something.

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: Nancy have any severe childhood illnesses? Scarlet Fever? High temperatures -- concussions?

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: Nightmares are expected after psychological trauma. Don't worry, they go away.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I sure as hell hope so.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: They're just simple tests, Nan. We'll both be right here.

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: Look, I know it's been frightening, I know your dreams have seemed real. But... it's okay. Okay?

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: How long's this been going on?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Since the murder. She was fine before that.

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: Not to worry. No signs of pathology in Nancy's EEG or pulse rate. I'd guess what we've got is a normal young girl who just happens to have gone through two days of hell.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: It's just made her think... her dreams are real...

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What the hell are dreams, anyway?

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: Mysteries. Incredible body hookus pokus. Truth is we still don't know what they are or where they come from. As for nightmares...  Did you know that in the last three years twenty Filipino refugees in California died in the middle of nightmares? Not from heart attacks, either. They just died.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What happened? That needle sank like a rock.

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: She's entering deep sleep now. Heart rate's a little high due to anxiety, but otherwise she's nicely relaxed. All normal. She could dream at any time now.  Right now she's like a diver on the bottom of an ocean no one's mapped yet. Waiting to see what shows up.

turns.speaker: DR KING
turns.text: R.E.M.'s. Rapid eye movements. The eyes follow the dream -- their movement picks up on this --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Oh my god, oh my god...

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Then bring us back its tail and whiskers.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: So we'll guard her together. Through the night.  In each others' arms like we always said.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Glen. Not now. I mean, we're here for Tina now, not for ourselves.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: Why's she so bothered by a stupid nightmare, anyway?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Because he was scary, that's why.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Oh -- jeez -- Glen! Rod's gone ape!

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Yeah. Something slippery all over here...  Tina?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Sometimes I wish you didn't live right across the street.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: Shut up and let me in. You ever stand on a rose trellis in your bare feet?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: M'god, I look twenty years old.  You have any weird dreams last night?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Well at least I have an objective wall to bounce this off.  You believe it's possible to dream about what's going to happen?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: You believe in the Boogey Man?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: One two, Freddie's coming for you? No. Rod killed Tina. He's a fruitcake and you know it.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: I believe in you, me, and Rock and Roll. And I'm not too sure about you lately.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Listen, I got a crazy favor to ask.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: It's nothing too hard or anything.  I'm just going to... LOOK for someone, and... I want you to be sort of a... guard. Okay?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Shhh. Now listen, here's what we're gonna do...

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Just checking -- keep out of sight!

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: Whenever I get nervous I eat.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: And if you can't do that, you sleep.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: You ever read about the Balinese way of dreaming?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: They got a whole system they call 'dream skills'. So, if you have a nightmare, for instance like falling, right?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: Instead of screaming and getting nuts, you say, okay, I'm gonna make up my mind that I fall into a magic world where I can get something special, like a poem or song.  They get all their art literature from dreams. Just wake up and write it down. Dream skills.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: And what if they meet a monster in their dream? Then what?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: They turn their back on it.  Takes away its energy, and it disappears.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: What happens if they don't do that?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: I guess those people don't wake up to tell what happens.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: I found it at this neat survivalist bookstore on Ventura.

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: Well what you reading it for?

turns.speaker: GLEN
turns.text: I heard your ma went ape at the security store today. You look like the Prisoner of Zenda or something. How long's it been since you slept?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Coming up on the seventh day. It's okay, I checked Guiness. The record's eleven, and I'll beat that if I have to.  Listen, I... I know who he is.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Yeah, and if he gets me, I'm pretty sure you're next.
